question: Kafka. The keeper of the files is still waiting for your final summation of the Erlanger claim.
answer: I gave it to him yesterday.

question: You didn't give it to me.
answer: No, I left it in his office.

question: Did you see him?
answer: I've never seen him. I don't believe there is a keeper of the files.

question: He's usually in the storage room sorting things out. He can't close the file on a case until he has the concluding report.
answer: He has it, he just hasn't noticed it yet, all right?

question: Who's to say he ever will? He's a timid old man and quite careful not to tread on anyone's toes -- In fact, I'm the only one he trusts and he wouldn't even look at a document if it didn't first come through me. In an organization as efficient as ours, if a document once in a great while gets lost it might never be found at all.
answer: Burgel, I thought it would be easier, as long as I was passing --

question: But I'm the messenger. An error like this damages my credibility.
answer: Your credibility -- yes, it's well known.

question: When I deliver a message the very act of delivering it, you might say, gives it an official stamp, and only in this way are both the sender and the receiver satisfied that it was delivered at all.
answer: I'll commit that to memory.

question: Your position in this firm is not unassailable.
answer: Has one more look over at the empty desk before returning to his work. I'm sorry to disturb you -- I wonder if you know where my friend Eduard is? -- I didn't want to bother you. My friend Eduard, I wonder if you've seen him? He hasn't been in to work, I thought he might be ill. You didn't have to get out of bed -- I could have taken the key. Well, he's not here. Do you think you ought to do that? Miss Rossmann? I'm Kafka -- I work upstairs in Accident --

question: Has one more look over at the empty desk before returning to his work. I'm sorry to disturb you -- I wonder if you know where my friend Eduard is? -- I didn't want to bother you. My friend Eduard, I wonder if you've seen him? He hasn't been in to work, I thought he might be ill. You didn't have to get out of bed -- I could have taken the key. Well, he's not here. Do you think you ought to do that? Miss Rossmann? I'm Kafka -- I work upstairs in Accident --
answer: I know.

question: You're a friend of Eduard Raban's.
answer: Why would you suppose so?

question: Oh -- well, I thought he once mentioned --
answer: One of you must be mistaken.

question: I'm sorry, but I just wondered --
answer: Excuse me, I have to copy this for Central Docketing by 2:30.

question: --On the other hand, is an enticement. Kafka can't help walking towards her. Sitting with her own friends, though there is something less than friendly about them. Two men, two women. Hello again.
answer: I've never seen you here before.

question: Have you looked?
answer: Well -- nice to know life exists outside the office.

question: Yes.
answer: No, really, I have to go home too.

question: Has a private moment with Kafka. Where do you live?
answer: Up there.

question: I tried finding a place on Castle Hill when I arrived. I wanted to share the majesty.
answer: It's only majestic from here. When you get closer you see it for what it really is.

question: What is it really?
answer: A glorified office block. They keep all the old records there -- the final resting place for facts and figures that have ceased to matter in the world of the living.

question: Well, as long as I admire it from afar it shouldn't worry me if it's hollow.
answer: It's more than hollow. It's stillborn. For all its size it serves no purpose. It's just there -- like death -- hovering over a breathing city.

question: I'm writing a story about a man who wakes up one morning to find himself transformed into a giant insect. Turns to go -- when he notices Bizzlebek leaning listlessly in the coffee house doorway. A figure in the shadows.
answer: I've read your stories. They're fantastic.

question: I don't know what you could have read.
answer: Just what you've published.

question: -- In magazines nobody reads.
answer: I read the one about the penal colony.

question: Did you?
answer: The needles inscribing the judgement into the flesh of the man. Very good. If I could sculpt as well as that, I'd be quite proud of myself.

question: "As Gregor Samsa awoke one morning from disturbing dreams he ... from unsettling dreams ... uneasy dreams ... Gregor Samsa ... Gregor ...?" Carl. George. Rudolf ... ... Yes. ... Yes.
answer: Kafka -- is that your real name?

question: Yes. Yes, of course -- why wouldn't it be?
answer: When was the last time you saw Mr. Raban?

question: Wednesday. We left the office together.
answer: Did you go anywhere afterwards -- to have a drink perhaps?

question: No, we said goodbye outside the building. He went off, as usual, toward his house.
answer: Your office is the Workmen's --

question: -- Accident and Compensation Association.
answer: Where you've been employed for seven years.

question: Eight -- and seven months.
answer: Engaged in the manufacture and distribution of ... pills and so forth.

question: Well -- other departments are, yes.
answer: Would you describe your relationship with the dead man as close?

question: Yes. Since he came to the office, almost three years ago, we've been quite good friends. How was Eduard ...
answer: He was found in the River. Could he swim?

question: I don't know.
answer: Was he depressed?

question: No. He didn't seem to be. Do you think he drowned himself?
answer: Grown men don't normally fall into the river, do they?

question: No, I suppose not.
answer: He might have had a drink or two, despite what you think.

question: Can I ask -- how you found me?
answer: His landlady knew of no other friends to refer us to.

question: I don't think he really had any. He had no family either.
answer: We know that.

question: He wasn't a lonely man, though.
answer: What makes you think so?

question: ... Just a perception.
answer: I don't usually involve myself with you people in the Old Quarter -- but the River runs its own course. It won't be the last time it deposits its unwanted debris on my doorstep.

question: Probably not.
answer: Anyway, I'd like you to reflect that in me you have -- I won't say a friend, because we're complete fencers, of course -- from distinctly incompatible social classes -- but to some extent, shall we say, an interested third party.

question: I'll bear that in mind.
answer: -- Should you happen upon anything that might be relevant.

question: The noise causes him to turn around. He watches the trolley as it's pushed past. Edges out of the way to let it by, feeling as though it has been made for him, is waiting for him. You wanted to see me, sir.
answer: Sit down, Kafka. You've been with the firm for nearly nine years. You've done your work diligently, there are no complaints on that score. But there's more to the job than the work -- there are other people to consider -- and frankly, Kafka, we eel your social situation could bear improving.

question: ... My ... social situation?
answer: You keep too much to yourself -- you're a lone wolf. It makes me uneasy, and if it makes me uneasy I can't imagine the impression you make on lesser employees.

question: To do my work well, I have little time for --
answer: You must make the time. Where do you go off to in the lunch hour?

question: I usually take lunch by the River.
answer: It's not healthy, Kafka -- not for you and not for your workmates. At the annual dinner this month you again failed to make an appearance.

question: I did not realize it was obligatory.
answer: Have you never wondered -- and I mention this only in passing -- why other clerks have advanced to more responsible positions while you, who have been here longer, have not?

question: No, sir.
answer: Attitude, Kafka. It doesn't matter how well you do your work -- you still see it as something to be gotten on with rather than something to take an active interest in.

question: Well, I --
answer: Oh, I know you got along with that poor fellow -- what was his name?

question: -- Eduard --
answer: -- Yes -- Raban -- but he was too much like you -- even more so perhaps. He wasn't here as long as you, so I didn't know him as well -- but I could see the influence he was having. I simply want you to be aware of this because you'll be happier for it. In any case -- don't ask me why -- the word has come down you're to be promoted. Your colleague's death has helped precipitate the need, though I can tell you it's been under consideration for some time. You're to be given two assistants and a commensurate rise in salary. That's all. Kafka. I understand you fancy yourself an author.

question: In a small way.
answer: You might find a more athletic hobby -- put some color in your cheeks.

question: She looks distressed, walking tall as if to bolster her composure. Sneaky Burgel does not help matters by characteristically appearing from the sidelines.
answer: Good morning -- Or should I say good afternoon?

question: Say what you like -- no one pays the least attention.
answer: Oh, don't they? I think you underestimate my station in this office and overrate your own.

question: Not today, Burgel. Send one of your memos, write up one of your communiques, but for God's sake don't bother me today.
answer: It's my place to offer advice, not yours -- and by advising the Chief Clerk of your unpunctuality it's certainly not my situation that's compromised, if that's what you're implying.

question: You're just doing your job.
answer: It's what I'm paid to do.

question: You're detestable.
answer: And you're late!

question: You look like brothers.
answer: Yes -- we do.

question: Have you worked here long?
answer: No, no, no -- quite a long time, yes.

question: Well, we'd better move things from my old desk.
answer: Look at each other with identical frowns, then back at Kafka. Oskar nods, as if to say "oh, all right, if we must." And Ludwig grins.

question: Eduard and I had lunch together one day ... and you saw us.
answer: On the Embankment.

question: I was having an affair with Eduard. He didn't tell you?
answer: No.

question: He would have. You were his best friend. A better friend than me.
answer: I suspected that he -- well.

question: What?
answer: That he was -- satisfied in that regard. I didn't want to pry.

question: It's not that we wanted to deceive anyone -- but you know how these things are looked upon at the office. What's funny?
answer: This morning it was suggested to me that my own sense of office fellowship could bear improving.

question: As long as it's on their terms. If your work and your private life don't correspond to their specifications you're labelled a dangerous agitator -- with no recourse whatsoever.
answer: How long were you and Eduard --

question: Two or three months, that's all. -- I seduced him. You know as well as I do that he didn't commit suicide.
answer: No, I don't. I'm amazed that anyone is able to bear life with any assurance at all.

question: Eduard didn't see it as something that needed bearing.
answer: The police would know the difference, wouldn't they?

question: Do you think people in the New Town care what happens over here? This will always be the ghetto.
answer: He wasn't robbed. He was identified by his wallet.

question: And you believe everything the authorities tell you.
answer: When I have no reason to doubt.

question: The very fact that they're authorities should give you reason. People will do anything to protect their own interests. For all you know he was killed at the hands of the police.
answer: -- What could he have done to warrant that?

question: Turns back to Kafka. Are you free tonight?
answer: Tonight?

question: There are some people I'd like you to meet. Can you come to the Musil district at eight o'clock?
answer: ... All right.

question: You almost married recently, didn't you?
answer: Last year. I -- it was broken off.

question: Eduard wanted to marry me.
answer: And you ...?

question: I'm suspicious of men who want to marry. I believe they think it's the only thing that will make them equal to their fathers.
answer: Stays where he is a moment, watching her. He may have found his ideal woman. -- I don't know the Musil district.

question: So that's who my foes are -- policemen and file clerks. Law and order, you might say.
answer: You think what we're doing is so wrong? And what are you doing? Pursuing goodness? For what? To answer to some supreme tribunal?

question: My only concern is the human tribunal. Isn't it yours?
answer: Yes -- which is why "quiet, dependable people" have to take charge of their own lives.

question: At the cost of others? You accuse people of murder without trial -- apparently without irony. Did you go to the Castle with Eduard? Then you have no idea what really might have happened that night at all -- even before or after he got there.
answer: Your human tribunal will betray you. Just as its members will be betrayed when they find no supreme one Join us, Kafka. It's sheer folly for anyone to try to pull through alone.

question: Yes.
answer: I'm collecting Eduard's things. If there's anything you want, take it or I'll give it to charity.

question: Burgel gave me this -- what does it mean?
answer: Burgel! -- I didn't leave it with him.

question: Why were you given notice?
answer: They're not obliged to tell.

question: It couldn't be for that incident with Burgel the other day.
answer: Of course it could -- Burgel's been trying to get me thrown out as long as I can remember. He could've killed Eduard.

question: You don't believe that.
answer: I wouldn't put it past him.

question: It seems I knew Eduard a little bit, after all.
answer: You might think -- I thought so myself at first -- that Burgel's too insignificant to be dangerous. But that's the very reason to beware! It's the small men to watch out for -- the ones who substitute method for character.

question: Now you've fallen into his trap. When he goes to bed at night Burgel dreams of inspiring as much fear in others as they inspire in him.
answer: It's still easier for you to understand suicide, isn't it.

question: That street down there -- I always used to call it the approach road for suicides. It leads straight down to the bridge and the River.
answer: Burgel hated Eduard. And me. I'm sure he knew about us -- and I'm sure it drove him mad.

question: Burgel doesn't like anybody!
answer: He used to like me -- very much more than I liked him.

question: He's jealous, yes, but that jealous? He's too cautious.
answer: Of course he is -- the Castle precincts are not the safest part of the city after dark. People disappear up there regularly. If you want to lie in wait for someone, that's the place to do it.

question: Now you're saying Eduard was lured there?
answer: How often does one of our clerks have business in the house of records?

question: I've heard of it happening.
answer: And Burgel is the bringer of messages, isn't he?

question: Usually.
answer: Or what if there really was an error? -- I don't know what kind -- any kind that needed correcting -- and what if Burgel was responsible for it? One mistake -- even a small one in a firm like ours -- it could cost him a promotion.

question: First these nameless authorities were the root of all evil, now it's insignificant Burgel. If indeed there was a mistake -- and a minor one at that -- you're suggesting someone went to a lot of trouble over something so trivial as to not matter at all.
answer: What seems important to these people is not determined by the amount of work it entails -- you're far from understanding the authorities if you believe that.

question: Now Burgel's one of the authorities?
answer: For all his big talk he is. Does he really have access to the Directors of the firm as he always claims? -- or only the Deputy Managers -- people of no importance whatsoever. Someone ought to follow him for a change.

question: You won't make any sense of it while you're upset.
answer: Burgel is only there for one purpose -- to spy on the employees and report any and all indiscretions, real or imagined. If he didn't send Eduard to the Castle, you can be damn sure he's in league with whoever greeted him there. All those bastards are in league with each other -- why can't you see that!

question: ... I don't see anything. I see a message on its way to me -- with all the right answers. Only it never arrives -- it's always just on its way.
answer: Eduard ... Your ignorance of the way things are here is so appalling that it makes my head spin to listen to you and compare what you say and have in mind with the real situation! Rushing down the stairs in anger, tearing open the door at the middle landing and slamming that one too once past it.

question: Following her down.
answer: Coming down the final flight of stairs, disappearing through the door at the bottom, slamming that one as well.

question: Almost caught up with her, coming down to the last door.
answer: You said she was extremely upset. People who are extremely upset -- Kafka -- are given to disappearing in a hurry. They go and calm down for a day or so and then they come back.

question: But that's just my point -- she was more than upset, she was livid. She slammed every door on her way downstairs -- except that one. I was just behind her and I didn't even hear that one shut -- not at all.
answer: That's not what I call conclusive evidence of an abduction.

question: If someone was waiting here in the hallway to spirit her away, wouldn't they have shut the door as quietly as possible?
answer: Why would someone want to kidnap this woman -- the name is Rossmann?

question: You told me to contact you if anything relevant came up -- Gabriela is relevant. When I spoke to you before I didn't know she'd been seeing Eduard.
answer: That's been noted. But where does it lead us? Unless you have something more to add.

question: She's missing. I went to her house and she hadn't returned there.
answer: She lost her job today. Just between you and me, I'd probably go away and brood a bit myself.

question: Maybe it's true then what she said.
answer: What did she say?

question: That the police may have allegiance to something other than truth. -- She didn't think Eduard committed suicide. Any more than I do. She was convinced of it.
answer: I'm going to say something, and I hope it's quite clear because I won't be repeating it. We don't have to hunt for criminals. We're drawn towards them. The guilty show us the way.

question: Where are your friends?
answer: Good question. Who are my friends ... would also be of interest. Gabriela was right -- it's easier for me to understand suicide. I'm a practicing suicide.

question: -- In what sense?
answer: Bachelorhood is just the slow form. The bachelor doesn't sew seeds. Only the moment matters. The space he occupies grows smaller and smaller -- until the only space right for him is his coffin.

question: These strange stories you write -- they come naturally, do they?
answer: Naturally? -- that's not the word I would have chosen.

question: Where do you get your ideas? Only joking -- I'm just joking. Let's go to a brothel then, Kafka, come on.
answer: I haven't got the energy. I mean, I have to conserve my energy.

question: Why do you work in that hideous insurance office? -- dealing with people who fall off ladders. Now take me -- I make my living as a stone mason. It's not my art -- but it's the tools of my art. You could be -- a journalist.
answer: That would be even worse -- it would be a compromise.

question: Success or nothing?
answer: No -- not even success. My writing is not for making a living -- it's for living. Not for other people, it's for me. ... I'm the exile. Gabriela was right about that too.

question: -- The crime so scandalous that the poor young clerk committed suicide rather than own up to it.
answer: That's mad.

question: -- Oh, yes, it's mad.
answer: -- You said so yourself the firm is large and powerful. If the discrepancy really was something big, Eduard's responsibility would still have to be small. No poor young clerk could find himself in such a fix.

question: "Raban" -- that'll be nearly at the back of the alphabet.
answer: It usually is.

question: I'm not obliged to give you access, you know -- not without authorization -- but I'll make an exception this one time. I'm overworked as it is. "Raban" did you say?
answer: Yes. Isn't it there?

question: Wait a minute. "Raban?" Where have I heard that name?
answer: He's the clerk who died last week. From the insurance department What's the matter?

question: Why would we keep files on dead employees? All old files are sent up to the Castle. Do you think we have room for two hundred years worth personnel records?
answer: It's gone out so quickly?

question: Whenever an employee departs, shall we say, it's up to the head of his department to requisition his file, reassign any outstanding claims, and send it off.
answer: -- You mean my Chief has it. Excuse me, sir -- I understand you have Eduard Raban's file.

question: -- You mean my Chief has it. Excuse me, sir -- I understand you have Eduard Raban's file.
answer: I do.

question: I wonder if I might look to see if there's an address for family -- I thought I'd like to write to them.
answer: No -- just as I thought -- no entry for family. Was there something else?

question: No -- I just -- I feel a sense of obligation. He was my friend -- if I can be of any help -- closing his affairs.
answer: No, there's only one report to complete. I'll be doing it myself and submitting it to the Castle today or tomorrow.

question: I see -- it's just the Erlanger claim then.
answer: The Orlac claim.

question: Sorry, yes -- well -- thank you, sir.
answer: Kafka. You're too sensitive. Let your friend rest in peace. I've known suicides. Such a song- and-dance about nothing.

question: Yes, sir.
answer: Give it up.

question: If it was Accounts you wanted why did you ask for Employees?
answer: Orlac is an account?

question: It's a factory in the northern mountains. One of our best customers. Without a proper request I'm not obliged to do this, you understand -- but I'll make an exception on this one occasion. At least the account is current even if the employee isn't. That place has so many accidents, it's a good thing the type of peasants who live up there don't seem to have any trouble propagating their race.
answer: All these in the last year?

question: You must have read about it in the papers -- there was a terrible cave-in. It wouldn't have been so bad, but even the Medical Officer for the district was killed!
answer: I did read that. They gave him a posthumous medal.

question: Dr. Murnau was the bravest of men. He spent an entire career in those backwaters with no regard for personal gain. A great loss.
answer: This is the cross-reference of clerks who've worked on Orlac claims?

question: Is your friend's name among them? Then he only worked on the one case. Your Chief will send me the final summation when he's finished with it.
answer: Once a file's been sent to the Caste, is it possible to recall it for review?

question: Of course not. Only by a Director of the firm. Who'd want to let in all kinds of riff-raff off the streets?
answer: What good are records if they're not open for public inspection?

question: These laws have been with us for centuries -- how can you doubt them?
answer: What if I petitioned one of the Directors?

question: You do not summon them -- they summon you -- and this, of course, hardly ever happens, if at all. The Directors are an eccentric lot and by nature cautious.
answer: Where do our records go to in the Castle?

question: We're a medical firm, aren't we? They go to the Medical Records Section.
answer: I could always apply there.

question: One is sweeping the floor. The other is scribbling at their desk. His pen blotches his paper. He has a fit and crumples it up and throws it down.
answer: Looks over at the Chief Clerk's office -- sees him writing intently at his desk, pausing to turn on a lamp.

question: The sweeping one bangs his knee against a desk and starts hopping about. The pen of the other one leaks again. He crumples up his new sheet and flings it away even more angrily than before. Then he examines his pen, determines that the cap at the back is loose, and starts banging it on his desk in an attempt to tighten it -- while the other assistant keeps jumping around holding his hurt kneecap.
answer: Glances over his shoulder at them, starts to say something -- but then notices Burgel, not far away, sometimes blocked by other employees, walking in the direction of the Chief Clerk's office.

question: The one assistant has just fixed his pen when the other one, still hopping around, bumps into him, causing him to knock over a bottle of ink. The two of them start shoving each other about.
answer: Do you mind!

question: You've dropped some money. You work in the cemetery.
answer: A man must eat -- And drink.

question: The Castle cemetery.
answer: Are you sure you wouldn't prefer going through official channels?

question: Official channels -- a lot of good they've done me. My only hope is to approach the officials personally.
answer: -- I'm flattered, of course, to be considered a friend -- even without knowing all the details. -- To see such determination is reward enough for me.

question: The Kafka men are famous for it, you know. Delivering meat barefoot in the depths of winter, picking up sacks of flour with their teeth -- -- Oh, yes, determination runs in the family.
answer: There is one thing I'd like you to tell me.

question: I'm trying to find things out myself -- that's the whole point.
answer: What made you think I'd be able to get you into the Castle?

question: The cemetery is nearer the Castle than anywhere else -- wasn't it part of the Castle originally? -- I always assumed there'd be a gate or something. Isn't there?
answer: In a manner of speaking. I was restoring some stones here in the upper section one day -- and I found this.

question: An empty tomb?
answer: A cenotaph -- a monument to someone whose remains ended up elsewhere. But look -- The Castle gates were blockaded in the time of the great plague -- it's an escape route. Don't get stuck.

question: Not a chance. I'm the thinnest person I know. -- You appreciate my writing.
answer: Yes.

question: Will you do me a favor then?
answer: Another one?

question: If I don't see you later -- go to my house and find my notebooks -- and destroy them. All my manuscripts -- just burn them. Please.
answer: What an extraordinary request!

question: It's my last and final one.
answer: Then its authority is in doubt.

question: A true friend would do it.
answer: Not necessarily. A wife would.

question: I assume you're wondering ... what all this has been about.
answer: Are you the Head of Medical Records?

question: He's come on his own initiative. -- Not something we encourage, mind you, but we like to know it exists. What it amounts to is simply this ... A piece of paper was delivered to the wrong clerk. It was essential he bring it back to us. These complications have arisen because he had friends -- like you, among others -- friends unlikely to let a sleeping dog lie.
answer: ... A piece of paper ...

question: A mere slip. Your friend Mr. Raban dealt only with claims that came in, another department being responsible for compensation that goes out -- this is correct? Through a very unfortunate -- and I might add extremely rare -- mishap, a document intended for the one department was sent to the other. And for the first time -- though your friend wasn't aware of it -- two and two could have been put together to make one.
answer: ... A piece of paper ...

question: You see, Kafka, in all cases relating to the factory at Orlac -- which is what this paper referred to -- the authority that puts in a request and the authority that grants it is, to all intents and purposes, the same authority. -- You seem amused.
answer: It only amuses me in that it gives me an insight into the ludicrous bungling that in some circumstances may decide the life of a human being.

question: It's merely a matter of expediency. It's imperative that my room to maneuver not be hindered by ... bureaucratic ramifications. -- If an obscure official up there in the distant mountains so far away from civilizing influences happens to meet with an unfortunate accident -- and should he tragically die in spite of the District Medical Officer's strenuous efforts to save him -- the firm wants to see the next of kin pacified and the disposition of the remains handled with the greatest possible ... efficiency.
answer: "Accident and Compensation" -- no one can accuse the firm of not supplying exactly what it promises.

question: I believe we've exceeded his expectations.
answer: I had the grandest of financial plots in mind, the most malevolent of personal motives, conspiracy theories extending to every ... authority I could see. And I find you. A body snatcher.

question: Life is more than a Chinese puzzle, my friend.
answer: And I suppose Dr. Murnau didn't die in a cave-in. You killed him to free the Position of Orlac Medical Officer for your own ends.

question: Yes, well -- we're looking for a new village now. If we stay too long at one source ... people become suspicious. But you're quite right that he didn't die in that cave-in. In fact, he didn't die at all. He was simply recalled -- by himself. As well as being Head of Medical Records here and a Director of your firm -- I'm Dr. Murnau, of course. May I ask where your two warders are?
answer: Lying in the gutter where they belong.

question: Pity. They're an amusing pair, didn't you find? Absolute innocents. I so rarely get the chance of showing my work to anybody -- anybody capable of appreciating it, that is. You might say I'm a student of human reaction.
answer: The fact that it's live bodies you practice your trade on doesn't seem to matter to you.

question: On the contrary, it matters a great deal. We're engaged in immensely important research here. I'm a revolutionary too, you know -- but a much more pragmatic one. -- I can't very well administer experimental treatments to corpses -- and if they become corpses, why, they have their uses too -- that's why speed is essential. Living tissue, even if its owner has passed on, is our most valuable acquisition. We've tried transfusions on our ... volunteers. Unfortunately, far from infusing superior characteristics it's tended to make them insane -- murderous even -- a condition we've had occasion to make use of. -- And the new patients they bring me aren't usually as dexterous as you've been in evading us. Not perfect specimens by any means, but not the type of person who'll be missed either.
answer: What have you done with Gabriela Rossmann?

question: As a matter of fact you've caught us in a state of considerable excitement. Our latest preparation we believe -- we pray -- is perfected. It should take years off her. And if not -- well, there are always what I call my caprices of vivisection. Actually, if it weren't for the aberrant dilemma posed by someone like yourself -- continually asking for out-of-date files -- I'd probably give up my revisionist policies altogether. I'm sure what we have to do is start instead at the very inception -- with the embryo -- from a single cell even. The lure of the Golem -- the man-made man. You appreciate that, I know. To corrupt the image of man and then offer redemption ... This is the dawn, Kafka. A new man is being born here. A more resilient man ... A superman. To a new world -- of Gods and monsters.
answer: Throws Ekman aside and runs away.

question: Walks slowly, tiredly. He looks up at the sky, but the sky is a silver shield against anyone who looks for help from it.
answer: Standing there, half in shadow, in profile. Her glorious profile.

question: Gabriela! -- you did get away.
answer: I knew you walked this way to work. I wanted to find you before they did.

question: -- I've just come from the Castle. It's over.
answer: Over? It's only over when you can crawl to a clean little spot on earth where the sun sometimes shines and you can warm yourself a bit.

question: Gabriela ...?
answer: Should I tell you why I joined our late lamented nihilists? Why I became a murderer? Because murder ... is bliss. It's easier than you might think to absorb and assimilate Evil -- once you've adopted its procedure. Have you ever watched a person deteriorate? Day by day. I don't mean in a spiritual sense. Only two steps back? Even the man they left to guard me retreated further than that.

question: I -- I found your jailer.
answer: This is the result of their elixir of youth. They were to come and check on it during the night. I contrived to miss the appointment.

question: They're dead now. We can get help.
answer: I know how they reward failure. If they saw this I'd be rotting in the quarries by the afternoon -- with all the others.

question: There's a new potion -- he said it was perfected.
answer: I know there is. And you're what I have to bargain with. For now you're the last one in their way.

question: I told you, they're dead. It's finished.
answer: Why should I believe a man who never believed me? They're absolutely right, you know -- guilt should never be doubted. It's easier that way. I think you've just escaped for the moment. Just as I did. As Eduard did. As they let us do. But only for the moment.

question: No -- not this time.
answer: I know better than you what people will say when they have to. When they brought me in for questioning I informed on my friends the very first day.

question: -- Listen to me --
answer: I do. Always. You understand the world better than any of us, Kafka. And what it's becoming. I've always held you in the highest regard.
